# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.9c707c1d:
# Potential uses

*1. by what_timeframe, identify which what_frequencies are more relevant*

Purpose: identify if the categorization within what_timeframe is associated predominantly to a subset of frequencies

*2. by keyword in what_frequencies, distribution across what_end*

Purpose: identify which keywords are restricted to specific year range(s) (using what_end, and assuming that what_start, not shown, is always 2020)
source.051946a0:
# Additional sources

The [documentation of the dataset and its rationale are available on Kaggle](https://www.kaggle.com/robertolofaro/l-772020-20200717-word-frequencies-timeframe)

See the full dataset, including also the law subdivisions shown as text; each "item_id" is one article within the law

If needed, the source text of each item_id is [available here on GitHub](https://github.com/robertolofaro/decretorilancio)

A navigation webapp, along with a description of the reason why that "what_end" (and, consequently, the clustering into "what_timeframe") was assigned is on [my website](https://robertolofaro.com/legge77)
